BALTIMORE, MD., NOVEMBER

2, 1914.

PRICE, FIVE CENTS

MUSICAL CLUBS RUN BY BOARD

BRASS BANDS TO HELP ROOTERS

LAYFIELD INJURED ON SATURDAY

LEHIGH DOWNS VARSITY ELEVEN

Committee of Managers to Control This
Year's Concerts, Funds and Schedule.
Spieker to Lead Glee Club.

Hopkins Singing at Western Maryland
and St. John's Games Will Be Accompanied by "Some Noise."

Varsity Quarterback Carried From Field
to Hospital Had Made a Beautiful
Tackle,and Was Hurt in Fall.

Hopkins Plays Gritty Game, But Is No
Match for Heavier and More Experienced Team—Score, 33 to 0.

The Musical Clubs held their
second meeting on Wednesday and
completed organization.
The new constitution prepared
by the .committee was read, article
by article, and approved by the
whole body.
As was decided last week, the
entire management of the Clubs
will be in the hands of a board of
managers, consisting of five members. This board will select a secretary and treasurer from its personnel, and will act as a unit in obtaining engagements, managing the
funds, etc.
After the constitution was approved, the remaining elections
were held. Edmund Spieker was
elected leader of the Glee Club and
Walter Geissel of the Instrumental
Club, both receiving unanimous
votes. These men, together with
Baker, the president of the entire
organization, and two members
from the Clubs at large, will constitute the board of managers. The
. two inembers-at-large
elected were
Owens, pianist for last year's Clubs,
and Fred P. Hall, president of the
1917 class.
Under the new constitution, the
leaders of the respective Clubs are
given full powers of training and
selection. To eliminate absence
from rehearsals and concerts a fine
Will be imposed
cut. It
is hoped in this for eachprevent
a
way to
recurrence of the very frequent and
"timely absences which characterized many of last year's concerts.
The dues have been fixed at three
dollars per annum, to be returned,
if possible, at the end of the year.
Any member of the University may
become a member of the organization. It is not necessary for him
to take an
active part in the Clubs'
activities--he may be a sort of silent
Partner, obtaining free admission to
all • cOncerts. Moreover, if any
money is made (luring the year, besides the return of the original
three dollars, -dividends will be paid
on the
stock—one dollar being considered a share. The Clubs want
not Only a successful financial sea!,on, but also desire that the entire
university take an active interest
in their
work.
From now on, the two Clubs will
complete their organizations separately. Music has been ordered
and rehearsals soon will commence.
The Clubs are a little late in beginning to prepare for their season,
but the organization, which has
caused the lateness, is the reason
Which has enabled them to have a
season at all, and the plans just

Following the Hopkins custom,
a brass band will assist the rooters
in producing enthusing din and inspiring discord at the games with
Western Maryland and St. John's,
to be played on November 21 and
26, respectively.
We are informed by explorers
that all peoples, even the most
primitive, are fond of something
which they regard as music. Not
only when feasting or dancing do
they love to hear the crash of cymbals or the roll of drums, but even
more when marching into battle
they long for the shrill squealing
of the wry-necked fife, or the dull,
monotonous booming of the tomtorn. What more appropriate then,
than that the Hopkins warriors
should be spurred on to slaughter
by strains of melody floating.over
from the concrete grand-stand.
The objection that the band invariably drowns the noblest efforts
of the loyal rooters is indeed a negligible one. The great purpose of
rooting is to make a noise—if the
band can make a louder noise, why
not encourage it to (10 so? Again,
in these prevalent hard times, any
movement which serves to give employment to an otherwise idle class
is indeed a praiseworthy one. Last
of all, "Jack" DeWitt, cheer leader,
would undoubtedly appreciate a
chance to rest.
It is just here, however, that an
unfortunate complication arises.
Strange, almost unaccountable, as
it may seem to those who have
heard the music, the band insists
upon being paid. And this affords
an opportunity for every Hopkins
man to show his college spirit. A
public subscription AM be held, and
the names of the committee authorized to collect the funds will be
published in the columns of THE
NEWS-LETTnR. The rest will depend on every separate and individual student at the University.
Do your part, and see that your
friends do theirs. Christmas is a
long way off yet, so we can all
afford to give a little bit. Let's
make provision for a concert that
Nvill make Sousa and Victor Herbert green with envy, and leave the
Boston Symphony panting ingloriously in our rear. The figures
are a little mixed here, but our one
paramount desire is clear: We want
to out-play our opponents in the
stands as well as on the field. We
want that band at Homewood.

Robert Layfield, quarterback of
the Hopkins football team, was injured in Saturday's game with Lehigh. He is in St. Luke's Hospital,
South Bethlehem, Pa., and with
him are his father, Manager Allen
F. Voshell, of the 'Varsity eleven,
and John L. Dorsey, last year's
manager, who went to South Bethleham to see the game.
Layfield was injured in the early
part of the second period. He was
playing far behind the line when
Mattern, Lehigh's right halfback,
started out on a long end run.
Mattern got away from all the Hopkins players except Layfield, and
was coming down through an open
field toward the goal posts when
the little quarterback made a flying tackle to stop the run. He
downed Mattern, landing under
him when they fell. Mattern got
up, but Layfield could not move.
He was carried from the field by a
Lehigh player.
Manager Voshell and Dorsey
were on the side lines and immediately took the player to St. Luke's
Hospital, where some of the best
doctors in South Bethlehem examined him. The surgeons would not
make a statement until an X-ray
photograph had been made. This
was done Sunday morning, and it
was seen that his back had not been
broken as had been said in dispatches sent out Saturday night.
He is paralyzed from the waist
down, and it is believed that he has
suffered some injury to the spinal
cord, the nature of which is not revealed. His condition was reported unchanged early Monday morning. A consultation of doctors will
be held, to determine what course
to pursue to bring about recovery.
Layfield is a resident of Wilmington, Del. He studied at
Friends' School there and played
end on the football team. His
father, W. R. Layfield, is president
of the Atlas Powder Works. In
Baltimore he lives at the Central
Young Men's Christian Association.
Immediately after he was taken
to the hospital his father was notified, and Hopkins players returning
home after the game met Mr. Layfield in Philadelphia. Coaches Cates
and Hunter (lid not accompany the
team on the trip.
Captain Paul Wilkinson, too, was
injured slightly in the third quarter. He was carrying the ball and
was touched by three Lehigh men,
whom Ile dragged several yards,
straining the muscles of his leg.

A squad of eighteen men journeyed to South Bethlehem Friday
afternoon to meet the heavy Brown
and White eleven of Lehigh, who
had a clean record of five victories
ahead of them.
For the first quarter Hopkins
played a decided aggressive game,
carrying the ball to within five
yards of the opponents' goal line
twice, when both times Lehigh's
line braced and forced Hopkins to
give the ball up on downs. It was
only at the end of this period that
Hopkins' goal line was endangered,
when Lehigh succeeded in placing
the pigskin on her opponents' '0yard line.
A few moments after the opening of the second quarter, Fullback
Hoban succeeded in crossing Hopkins' goal line for the Brown and
\\Mite's first tally, but missed goal.
Wilkinson kicked off to Lehigh
who, after a line plunge by Greene
and a forward pass to Sawtelle,
made their second score soon after
by well-inteferenced end runs. Lehigh had discovered a weak point
in the Hopkins line, the ends. The
ball was again put into play by
Wilkinson kicking off to Hallowell,
\dio caught the ball on the fiveyard line and was nailed on the 20yard mark. Two end runs netted
gains of 30 yards. On the next
play a shift formation was resorted
to, the whole team swerving around
our right end as interference for
the quarterback. The ends and
backfield men were swept off their
feet, with the exception of Bobbie
Layfield, who remained alone to
defend the goal. Diving under the
interference, he laid low his man
by the prettiest tackle seen this
season. .It was at this point that
Layfield received his injury which
forced him to retire from the game.
It was at the end of this quarter
that the Black and Blue threatened
to cross the Brown and White goal
line. Randall made a pretty forward pass of 20 yards to Wilkinson, who made 20 more before being downed. On the next play
Wilkinson was given the ball on
an off-tackle play which netted 20
yards more, placing the pigskin on
Lehigh's io-yard line. Here the
Brown and White held for the
necessary number of downs, forcing the ball to be given up on their
four-yard line.
Shortly after the opening of the
third quarter, Hallowell received
Randall's punt and dodging through
a broken field, ran 75 yards for a
touchdown. Captain Wilkinson re-

completed should tend to make that
season one of the most successful in
Hopkins' history.

1915 HULLABALOO UNDER WAY

CROSS COUNTRY CLUB AT WORK

First Meeting of the Board on Thursday
Night Is Brought Good-luck by a
Most Mysterious Witch.

Coach Joe England Supervises Daily
Runs at Homewood—Hopkins Team
to Compete at Lexington, Va.

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board held
its organization meeting Thursday
night at the home of J. Saulsbury
Short, editor-in-chief.
At this meeting plans for the
senior class-book were discussed,
and many interesting ideas and
suggestions were submitted.
The Board means to get down
to work at once and has decided
to hold its weekly meetings on
Tuesdays at one o'clock in the
Trophy Room. It was the general
opinion of those present that the
Hullabaloo, too, should be representative of the three lower classes,
as well as of the senior. The
heads of the editorial, art and
business departments reported progress. The Board already has a
"wealth of material" that it has
collected during the last two years.
Art Director Avra Warren invites
the entire University to hand in
Business
artistic contributions.
Manager Spencer reported that
many of the men of the senior
class had already had their pictures
taken. He also had suggestions to
make regarding the business end
of the Hullabaloo. The success of
the book depends to a large degree
upon the advertisements, and Mr.
Spencer urged the other departments of the Board to co-operate
with the advertising manager as
much as possible.
Members of the senior class
can have their pictures taken as
soon as they obtain a slip from
"Bill" Baker, who is in charge of
the photographic department. Judging by the progress made already,
there is no reason why the 1915
Hullabaloo ought not be the best
yet. The Board wants the cooperation of the entire student
body, and believes that there will
be an immediate response.
When the meeting of the Board
was over it found awaiting it a
"Hallowe'en party." While seated
at the table a "witch" entered bearing a placard saying "No Pumpkin
Heads on the 1915 Hullabaloo
Board." She next distributed roses
to the Board. To each rose was
attached a quotation wishing success to the 1915 book. Before the
Board was able to find out who
the "witch" was, she had vanished
as quickly as she had appeared.
The "witch's" visit was taken as a
favorable omen, and the Board
now believes that the success of
the book is assured. The delightful party was broken up by all
arising and singing the class's anthem, "Whan That Aprille," etc.,
to the tune of "Good Night
Ladies."
The members of the Board are
Short, Spencer, Warren, Baker,
Merrick, Brooks, Bartlett, Troxell,
Nicholson, Lindau, Weech and
Tarr.

As announced last week, Hopkins expects to send a team to participate in the cross-country run
which will be held at Lexington,
Va., under the auspices of the
Southern Intercollegiate Track Association. The small • number of
candidates for this team indicates
clearly that the student body is
lacking in interest, or active interest, at least.
While only about ten men are to
be sent to the event at Lexington,
the number of candidates so far
is disappointing.
Practice is held every afternoon
at Homewood at 5.20 o'clock under
the direction of Coach "Joe" England. The practice itself is very
simple, and requires only a little
time each afternoon. The candidates gradually increase the distance of their run until the required
distance is reached. There can be
no doubt that such a systematic
training is of physic41 benefit to the
candidates.
The men who have been reporting at Homewood are: Penniman,
Fred Hall, Strauss, Binford, Poole,
Brower and Niles. Several of these
men, however, are not candidates
for the cross-country team. Everhard Deems, '15, manager of the
track team, urges all candidates—
old and new—for the track team
to participate in this practice at
Homewood.
The date of the meet at Lexington has not been definitely arranged, but it will probably come
in the last week of this month.
The,building of the schedule of
the 1915 track team is already being carried on by Manager Deems.
On his list are the University of
Virginia, Lehigh and Navy, besides the regular annual opponents,
and meets or meetings with representative squads may be arranged.

$100 for an Essay on Peace.

The Lake Alohonk Conference
on International Arbitration offers
a prize of one hundred dollars for
the best essay on "International
Arbitration" by an undergraduate
student of the United States or
Canada.
The essay should not he longer
than five hundred words. The
award of the prize will be made at
the Lake Mohonk Conference in
May, 1915. Further details as to
the contest will be supplied by the
secretary of the Conference, Lake
Alohonk, N. Y.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

THE COTILLON DATES ANNOUNCED BIBLE CLASSES ORGANIZE SLOWLY
Three Dances This Academic Year Are
to Be Held on December 4,February
12 and May 1—Finances Good.

Committee Is Still Busy Campaigning for
Students, but the Acceptances Are
Unusually Small in Number.

The organization meeting of the
Cotillon Board was held last Monday, when the dates for the three
dances of the year were fixed. The
first cotillon will take place on Friday evening, December 4. The
others will be on February 12 and
May I.
• The affairs of the Board are in
better shape than ever before, as
a good financial balance was carried
over from last season. Therefore,
the dances are expected to prove
even more elaborate functions than
heretofore.
Chairman Allen F. Voshell is
already arranging .a better system
of chaperoning. Efforts will be
made to get faculty sanction for an
advance of the closing hour from
tmidnight to one o'clock. In the
past, there has been much "complaint" of the cutting short of
after-supper dances, and the hasty
dash for the cloakroom at twelve,
when "Louie" lifts his marvelous
fingers from the keyboard and deParts.
Of course, "Louie" will be with
us again, and there can be no doubts
as to the music when he and his
ragtime band are behind the McCoy Hall palms.

The first "cabinet meeting" of the
University Young Men's Christian
Association was held last Tuesday
evening. At this meeting of the
officers of the Association, which is
held annually, plans for •the year
were discussed in detail with the
view of increasing the influence of
the Association and its work among
the students. Several officers were
also elected. A. M. Warren, of the
senior class, was made chairman of
the meetings committee.
The Bible study committee continues its call for students to join
the Bible classes. The itIvitation
cards are being returned very slowly. Dr. Swartz's class in "The Difficulties of the Bible," which was
recently organized, will meet at
seven o'clock every Thursday.
To those students who are unable to attend the classes at the
University, a most cordial invitation
is extended by the Central Young
Men's Christian Association, where
similar meetings are held every
Tuesday night. At 6.20 o'clock a
light lunch is served at the small
price of 15 cents. From 7 to 7.45
o'clock the classes will rneet. "Live
wire" talks will be given by prominent local ministers of churches of
all denominations.
In answer to the Association's
call for students to teach foreigners
the English language, another student has applied and has been assigned a class at the Fayette Street
M. E. Church. He is Alfred Niles,
of the 1916 class. Niles is the
third man to take up this work.
Three more are still needed.
As has been customary in previous years, Dr. J. M. T. Finney,
of the Medical School, will deliver
his two lectures on "Hygiene." The
lectures are given primarily for the
benefit of the freshman class, but
invitation is extended to all members of the University. The lectures are of vital interest to every
college man.
The dates of the lectures have
not been definitely decided upon.
They will, most likely, occur on
consecutive Mondays in the latter
part of this month. Dr. Abercrombie, in former years, has excused those freshmen from the
gymnasium class who attended
these lectures.

1916 Hullabaloo Organizes.

The organization meeting of the
1916 Hullabaloo Board was held in
the Trophy Room at one o'clock
Thursday.
The meeting was opened with a
Speech by Editor-in-Chief Tingley,
who gave a brief outline of the
work that is to be accomplished
during the current year. The Board
was then formally divided into
three departments: literary, art,
and business, and committees were
appointed to take charge of each
of these branches. Photographic
work is of course included under the
general head of art. The present
Junior Class has several men who
are clever with the camera, and
snap-shots of an unusual character
are promised.
Under the head of elections,
Dorsey Richardson and Miles H.
McCormick were chosen to be
members of the Board. Both of
them were assigned to the literary
department. An art editor is still
to be chosen by competition among
the class draughtsmen, and Friday,
November 20, was set as the date
on which all contributions of aspirants for the position must be submitted.
The meeting closed with a discussion of methods for financing
tile Hullabaloo. Delinquent members of the class are urged to pay
their dues as promptly as they can,
and so make the work of the Board
easier.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 2, 1914.
Layfield's Injury.

The injury suffered by Quarterback Robert Layfield in Saturday's
game with Lehigh is the first accident of a serious nature to have
occurred to a Hopkins player in
many years.
He was a light man, but his speed
and pluck overcame the handicap
in weight, and he won his place on
the 'Varsity over several other candidates. He is popular and has
made a great many friends during
the month he has been at Hopkins.
It is because of this pluck and
Popularity that his friends of the
team and in the student body wish
for him a speedy recovery, and THE
NEWS-LTTER expresses this sentiment, reflecting the concern and
sympathy which are felt generally
because of his condition.
Saturday's Games and Varsity's Chances.

The decisive defeat of \Vestern
Maryland by St. John's on Saturday, 34 to o, has materially increased the complexity of speculation as to the outcome of this year's
struggle for the state championship.
Three weeks ago Maryland Agricultural College suffered defeat at
the hands of Western Maryland,
a week'later the Farmers won from
St. John's and now St. John's defeats Western Maryland by an
overwhelming score. An explanation may partly be found in the
fact that the Aggies braced after
their loss to Western Maryland and
faced St. John's with a much
stronger team than that which
played the up-state eleven; however, it is evident that the Annapolis team is putting up a good game,
and will undoubtedly be in fighting trim on Thanksgiving Day.
Circumstances point to a hard battle when Hopkins again meets its
old foe.
The other games still to be played
this year promise to be highly in-

Can Win State Championship.

The Maryland Aggies, since they
have defeated Hopkins and St.
John's, are beginning to lay claim
to the state championship.
They do not recall, however, that
they have been defeated by Western
Maryland, 20 to 13, and that St.
John's has defeated Western Maryland, 34 to o.
Thus, the race for the title becomes an almost hopeless tangle.
But the Aggies, although they have
put crimps in the aspirations of St.
John's and Hopkins, have been
"crimped" themselves by Western
Maryland. Western Maryland has
been defeated by St. John's. Should
Hopkins win from the Westminster
team, it is pointed out by followers
of the game in this state that the
championship will fall to the team
that is victorious in the HopkinsSt. John's game at Homewood on
Thanksgiving.
The state games so far have resulted:
Washington defeated Western
Maryland.
Hopkins defeated Washington.
Aggies defeated St. John's.
Aggies defeated Hopkins.
St. John's •defeated Western
Maryland.
Western Maryland defeated Aggies.
The Brass Band.

our musicians and must pay for
them ourselves. The time is close at
hand when a brass band will have to
be engaged, and it is up to the students to raise the necessary money
among themselves. The team will
need all the encouragement that the
rooters' stand can give—the coming games all promise to be hard
contests and the presence of a band
will help tremendously to make the
rooting a big success; therefore, let
every Hopkins man give all he can
to assist in making the support of
the team at the coming games as
full of "pep" as possible. The loyal
support of every single man is
necessary. Let us have a brass
band, and let us have a good one.
Above all, let us be on hand ourselves to a man so that when the
team is in a tight place we can cheer
our players on to the best of our
ability.

Bible Study Class Meets.

.The first of the meetings of the
Bible study classes, each of which
are to assemble once a week during
the next two or three months under the leadership of the Young
Men's Christian Association, was
held at noon on 'Thursday in Levering Hall.
As outlined in his talk on Thursday, Dr. Swartz intends to take up
the study of man and to show in
what ways he is "like the image
of God." "Then," continued Dr.
Swartz, "we will study briefly the
life of God and try to explain any
actions or parts of His life that arc
not clear."
There were about twenty-five
men present at this first meeting,
and, according to the list of Secretary Sutton, about ten other men
are in the class. The next meeting
will take place on Thursday, at
noon, and all members of the class
are requested to be present.

LACROSSE GETS AN EARLY START
Aspirants for the Varsity Twelve Begin
Practicing in Cage Organization
Meeting About December 1.

Although the first lacrosse game
is less than five months off, many
of the aspirants for the Black and
Blue twelve have begun to practice in the cage. It is pleasing to
the officials in this branch of sport
that there is such a good spirit in
evidence. They also wish to give
these men a word of encouragement for constant practice will show
up when the scrimmages begin.
The. first official steps toward
opening the lacrosse season will be
the organization meeting, which is
to be held on or about December I
—just after the close of the football season. Following this meeting, regular practices will be held
in the cage and as soon as the
weather permits, Captain Troxell
will take his men to Homewood for
outdoor practice.
The chances for new players to
make the team are exceptionally
bright this year, for a number of
veterans of the game have either
been barred from playing by the
four-year limit or have failed to
return to the University. The defense department of the twelve has
suffered badly from the loss of
players. Julian Sears, who saw
four years of service on the team,
will be barred from playing; Walter D. Sutton, captain and coverpoint of last year's team, has also
played four years; Victor Bridgman, who played the point position,
has graduated; Guy Hollyday,
known in lacrosse togs as "the bearcat," will be badly missed at third
defense; Benton Beatty, who did
not return to the University, played
center last season. On the attack,
Frankie LaMotte, who is now attending the University of Wisconsin, is the only man who did not
return.
In spite of the fact.that a number
of stars were lost last year, prospects for a twelve of the usual
Hopkins' standard a r e bright.
There are a number of new men at
the University who have some
knowledge of the game from playing at preparatory schools: Richard
Woodward, Alexander Wolfe, Robert Hoffman and Frank Sutton
were all regulars on last year's City
College championship team; Mealy,
from Polytechnic, and Nelson, of
Gilman's Country School, a r e
others who have shown prowess
with the stick.
It is practically certain that
Coaches Raney Wolfe and William
Schmeisser will again head the
coaching department, with Professor Edward Hulburt, of the 1911
championship team, as assistant
coach.
There has been some delay in the
completion of the schedule, and
Manager Hiram Woodward will
not be able to announce the dates

until next week. As has been the
custom for a number of years, the
alumni will be met in the first game
on the last Saturday in March at
Homewood. The remainder of the
schedule includes the same teams
that were met last year. All of the
games will be played at Homewood,
with the exception of those with
Swarthmore and Navy, which will
be staged on our opponents'
grounds.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

VIOLIN SOUNDS SUBJECT OF STUDY

FRESHIES HOLD SECOND MEETING

Dr. Hewlett, of Physics Department, Has
Specially Equipped Room in Which
He Analyzes "Fiddle's Squeak."

The Upper Classmen Make Appeals for
Larger Support for College Activities Constitution Adopted.

Dr. Clarence Wilson Hewlett, instructor in the department of physics, has been engaged for the past
few years in analyzing the complex sound waves sent out by violins, and in measuring the distribution of energy among the partials
of the tones produced.
The experiments performed were
carried on in a room, the floor,
ceiling, and walls of which were
covered with a preparation of flax,
so that reflection of the waves
might be minimized.
About forty resonators, tuned according to the diatonic scale, were
enclosed in a wooden case, of which
the front was made of thin celluloid. In the aperture of each of
these a small mica disk, carrying a
mirror, was suspended on a fine
quartz fibre. Rays from fixed
sources of light were reflected by
these mirrors on a scale placed a
short distance in front of the apparatus, and the zero reading noted.
When the violin was bowed, the
resonator, whose frequency was the
same as the fundamental note produced on the instrument, began to
vibrate, and the disk at its opening was twisted around. The intensity of its vibration was measured by the image which the mirror cast upon the scale. Vibrations
were likewise perceived in the few
other resonators corresponding, in
..period, to the upper partials.
In order to get more marked
differences, the experiments were
carried on with violins which musicians pronounced of good quality,
and with some very inferior ones.
The difference in quality of the
tones produced manifested itself in
the even distribution of energy
among the component parts of the
notes of the better instruments and
in the total irregularity in the
others. In tile first case, a large
percentage of the total energy was
expended on the fundamental, and
a decreasing amount on the upper
partials which averaged about four
in number. In the latter, there
were frequently vibrations of 12
partials, and no regular arrangement of the distribution of energy
among the component parts was observed, all of which really amounts
to the fact that cheap violins frequently squeak.
The energy measured was, of
course, expressed in ergs.
The judging of tone quality thus
having been brought to a measurable basis, it is not too much to
expect innovations in the design of
our violins and a change for the
better.

The freshmen held their second
meeting of the year last Thursday
at one o'clock in the chapel of the
Young Men's Christian Association.
The only class business of any moment was the ratification of a constitution.
The meeting was opened by a
general "raking over the coals" by
the leaders of various student activities, who eloquently deplored the
fact that the "fresilies" had not
responded to the calling of these
activities as unitedly as has been
the custom. "Hoy" Short, editorin-chief of THE NEws - LETTER,
made a strong appeal for more candidates to compete for the freshman
editorships. It seems that only
about one-third as many 1918 men
are competing for the jobs this
year as has been the custom in previous years. C. E. Deems asked for
larger attendance to the various
Bible classes. He pointed out that
the classes prove a source of pleasure, as well as knowledge, and that
they deserved the hearty support
of the freshmen. "Tommy" Troxell advised those of the class who
desired to go out for the lacrosse
team to go over to the cage and
limber up. Edmund Spieker solicited the support of the freshmen
to help make this season a successful one for the Glee Club. President Frank Sutton appealed to the
class to uphold its honor by doing
its part to further the success of the
various student activities.
The constiutional committee (Arthur Hooper, Morton Rothschild
and Page Nelson) submitted the
constitution for ratification. It was
accepted with a few minor changes.
The question of class colors and
class pins was discussed and it was
finally decided to put the matter in
the hands of a committee.

Dr. Mustard Issues New Book.

The Johns Hopkins Press announced the publication of "The
Piscatory Eclogues of Jacopo Sannavaro," edited by Dr. Wilfred P.
Mustard, collegiate professor of
Latin.
This is the second of a series of
studies in the Latin poetry of the
Renaissance, and is uniform with
the first study, "The Eclogues of
Baptista Mantuanus."
The book is dedicated to Dean
E. H. Griffin.

October 31, 1914.
To the .Editor of THE NEWS-LETTER:
SIR—The following is submitted

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

The Norman, Remington Co.

HOMEWOOD CHIMES RING AGAIN

NOT ALLOWED TO CARRY COLORS

Gilman Hall Bells Have Been Made Har-

Law Passed to Stop Socialist Demonstra-

monious and Will Now Tell the

tions Affects Harvard Students, and

Hours Without Complaint.

Neither Can Wave Red Flags.

The bells in the tower of the new
Gilman Hall at Homewood have
been filed and polished until they
are now harmonious:, and may ring
without affecting the nerves of
neighbors, at whose complaint they
were hushed three weeks ago.
When the chimes were installed
it was found that they were sadly
discordant. This alone was a cause
for complaint. But when they rang
quarter-hours at the wrong time,
neighbors notified the authorities of
the University that they were
alarmists and disturbers of the
peace. Of course people did not
understand that they had just been
installed and the false telling of
time was part of the experiments
being made by workmen to see if
the set of bells was satisfactory.
When the complaints were received, however, the bells were returned to the foundry. They have
been filed and polished, and when
returned to the tower will be in
perfect harmony.

Because the colors of Harvard
University are crimson and white,
students of the college probably
will be prevented by law from
carrying flags and pennants in parades and games in the Commonweath of Massachusetts.
Frequent Socialist demonstrations, all of them accompanied by
the waving of red flags, caused a
law to be passed prohibiting the
carrying of red flags in the State.
It was meant to apply to the Socialists, and their leaders now declare that if their followers can not
bear the flaming color, neither can
any one else, and they intend to
see to it that Harvard's crimson
receives the same treatment as their
own color. Harvard parades, they
point out, are always led by a standard bearer with a large red flag.
Theoretically' the law will prohibit Harvard's carrying a red flag,
and it is said that members of the
University student body will walk
down a Cambridge street with a
flag to be arrested and bring about
a test case of the law. The Supreme Court has already upheld a
decision affecting the Socialists,
and Harvard students believe it
would be interesting to see how the
law will be dealt out to them.
Should the judges prohibit Harvard's flags from appearing on the
streets, it is said that influential
alumni on the bench and at the bar
will see that the statute is repealed.

Committee of Managers to Control This
Year's Concerts, Funds and Schedule.
Spieker to Lead Glee Club.

Hopkins Singing at Western Maryland
and St. John's Games Will Be Accompanied by "Some Noise."

Varsity Quarterback Carried From Field
to Hospital Had Made a Beautiful
Tackle,and Was Hurt in Fall.

Hopkins Plays Gritty Game, But Is No
Match for Heavier and More Experienced Team—Score, 33 to 0.

The Musical Clubs held their
second meeting on Wednesday and
completed organization.
The new constitution prepared
by the .committee was read, article
by article, and approved by the
whole body.
As was decided last week, the
entire management of the Clubs
will be in the hands of a board of
managers, consisting of five members. This board will select a secretary and treasurer from its personnel, and will act as a unit in obtaining engagements, managing the
funds, etc.
After the constitution was approved, the remaining elections
were held. Edmund Spieker was
elected leader of the Glee Club and
Walter Geissel of the Instrumental
Club, both receiving unanimous
votes. These men, together with
Baker, the president of the entire
organization, and two members
from the Clubs at large, will constitute the board of managers. The
. two inembers-at-large
elected were
Owens, pianist for last year's Clubs,
and Fred P. Hall, president of the
1917 class.
Under the new constitution, the
leaders of the respective Clubs are
given full powers of training and
selection. To eliminate absence
from rehearsals and concerts a fine
Will be imposed
cut. It
is hoped in this for eachprevent
a
way to
recurrence of the very frequent and
"timely absences which characterized many of last year's concerts.
The dues have been fixed at three
dollars per annum, to be returned,
if possible, at the end of the year.
Any member of the University may
become a member of the organization. It is not necessary for him
to take an
active part in the Clubs'
activities--he may be a sort of silent
Partner, obtaining free admission to
all • cOncerts. Moreover, if any
money is made (luring the year, besides the return of the original
three dollars, -dividends will be paid
on the
stock—one dollar being considered a share. The Clubs want
not Only a successful financial sea!,on, but also desire that the entire
university take an active interest
in their
work.
From now on, the two Clubs will
complete their organizations separately. Music has been ordered
and rehearsals soon will commence.
The Clubs are a little late in beginning to prepare for their season,
but the organization, which has
caused the lateness, is the reason
Which has enabled them to have a
season at all, and the plans just

Following the Hopkins custom,
a brass band will assist the rooters
in producing enthusing din and inspiring discord at the games with
Western Maryland and St. John's,
to be played on November 21 and
26, respectively.
We are informed by explorers
that all peoples, even the most
primitive, are fond of something
which they regard as music. Not
only when feasting or dancing do
they love to hear the crash of cymbals or the roll of drums, but even
more when marching into battle
they long for the shrill squealing
of the wry-necked fife, or the dull,
monotonous booming of the tomtorn. What more appropriate then,
than that the Hopkins warriors
should be spurred on to slaughter
by strains of melody floating.over
from the concrete grand-stand.
The objection that the band invariably drowns the noblest efforts
of the loyal rooters is indeed a negligible one. The great purpose of
rooting is to make a noise—if the
band can make a louder noise, why
not encourage it to (10 so? Again,
in these prevalent hard times, any
movement which serves to give employment to an otherwise idle class
is indeed a praiseworthy one. Last
of all, "Jack" DeWitt, cheer leader,
would undoubtedly appreciate a
chance to rest.
It is just here, however, that an
unfortunate complication arises.
Strange, almost unaccountable, as
it may seem to those who have
heard the music, the band insists
upon being paid. And this affords
an opportunity for every Hopkins
man to show his college spirit. A
public subscription AM be held, and
the names of the committee authorized to collect the funds will be
published in the columns of THE
NEWS-LETTnR. The rest will depend on every separate and individual student at the University.
Do your part, and see that your
friends do theirs. Christmas is a
long way off yet, so we can all
afford to give a little bit. Let's
make provision for a concert that
Nvill make Sousa and Victor Herbert green with envy, and leave the
Boston Symphony panting ingloriously in our rear. The figures
are a little mixed here, but our one
paramount desire is clear: We want
to out-play our opponents in the
stands as well as on the field. We
want that band at Homewood.

Robert Layfield, quarterback of
the Hopkins football team, was injured in Saturday's game with Lehigh. He is in St. Luke's Hospital,
South Bethlehem, Pa., and with
him are his father, Manager Allen
F. Voshell, of the 'Varsity eleven,
and John L. Dorsey, last year's
manager, who went to South Bethleham to see the game.
Layfield was injured in the early
part of the second period. He was
playing far behind the line when
Mattern, Lehigh's right halfback,
started out on a long end run.
Mattern got away from all the Hopkins players except Layfield, and
was coming down through an open
field toward the goal posts when
the little quarterback made a flying tackle to stop the run. He
downed Mattern, landing under
him when they fell. Mattern got
up, but Layfield could not move.
He was carried from the field by a
Lehigh player.
Manager Voshell and Dorsey
were on the side lines and immediately took the player to St. Luke's
Hospital, where some of the best
doctors in South Bethlehem examined him. The surgeons would not
make a statement until an X-ray
photograph had been made. This
was done Sunday morning, and it
was seen that his back had not been
broken as had been said in dispatches sent out Saturday night.
He is paralyzed from the waist
down, and it is believed that he has
suffered some injury to the spinal
cord, the nature of which is not revealed. His condition was reported unchanged early Monday morning. A consultation of doctors will
be held, to determine what course
to pursue to bring about recovery.
Layfield is a resident of Wilmington, Del. He studied at
Friends' School there and played
end on the football team. His
father, W. R. Layfield, is president
of the Atlas Powder Works. In
Baltimore he lives at the Central
Young Men's Christian Association.
Immediately after he was taken
to the hospital his father was notified, and Hopkins players returning
home after the game met Mr. Layfield in Philadelphia. Coaches Cates
and Hunter (lid not accompany the
team on the trip.
Captain Paul Wilkinson, too, was
injured slightly in the third quarter. He was carrying the ball and
was touched by three Lehigh men,
whom Ile dragged several yards,
straining the muscles of his leg.

A squad of eighteen men journeyed to South Bethlehem Friday
afternoon to meet the heavy Brown
and White eleven of Lehigh, who
had a clean record of five victories
ahead of them.
For the first quarter Hopkins
played a decided aggressive game,
carrying the ball to within five
yards of the opponents' goal line
twice, when both times Lehigh's
line braced and forced Hopkins to
give the ball up on downs. It was
only at the end of this period that
Hopkins' goal line was endangered,
when Lehigh succeeded in placing
the pigskin on her opponents' '0yard line.
A few moments after the opening of the second quarter, Fullback
Hoban succeeded in crossing Hopkins' goal line for the Brown and
\\Mite's first tally, but missed goal.
Wilkinson kicked off to Lehigh
who, after a line plunge by Greene
and a forward pass to Sawtelle,
made their second score soon after
by well-inteferenced end runs. Lehigh had discovered a weak point
in the Hopkins line, the ends. The
ball was again put into play by
Wilkinson kicking off to Hallowell,
\dio caught the ball on the fiveyard line and was nailed on the 20yard mark. Two end runs netted
gains of 30 yards. On the next
play a shift formation was resorted
to, the whole team swerving around
our right end as interference for
the quarterback. The ends and
backfield men were swept off their
feet, with the exception of Bobbie
Layfield, who remained alone to
defend the goal. Diving under the
interference, he laid low his man
by the prettiest tackle seen this
season. .It was at this point that
Layfield received his injury which
forced him to retire from the game.
It was at the end of this quarter
that the Black and Blue threatened
to cross the Brown and White goal
line. Randall made a pretty forward pass of 20 yards to Wilkinson, who made 20 more before being downed. On the next play
Wilkinson was given the ball on
an off-tackle play which netted 20
yards more, placing the pigskin on
Lehigh's io-yard line. Here the
Brown and White held for the
necessary number of downs, forcing the ball to be given up on their
four-yard line.
Shortly after the opening of the
third quarter, Hallowell received
Randall's punt and dodging through
a broken field, ran 75 yards for a
touchdown. Captain Wilkinson re-

completed should tend to make that
season one of the most successful in
Hopkins' history.

1915 HULLABALOO UNDER WAY

CROSS COUNTRY CLUB AT WORK

First Meeting of the Board on Thursday
Night Is Brought Good-luck by a
Most Mysterious Witch.

Coach Joe England Supervises Daily
Runs at Homewood—Hopkins Team
to Compete at Lexington, Va.

The 1915 Hullabaloo Board held
its organization meeting Thursday
night at the home of J. Saulsbury
Short, editor-in-chief.
At this meeting plans for the
senior class-book were discussed,
and many interesting ideas and
suggestions were submitted.
The Board means to get down
to work at once and has decided
to hold its weekly meetings on
Tuesdays at one o'clock in the
Trophy Room. It was the general
opinion of those present that the
Hullabaloo, too, should be representative of the three lower classes,
as well as of the senior. The
heads of the editorial, art and
business departments reported progress. The Board already has a
"wealth of material" that it has
collected during the last two years.
Art Director Avra Warren invites
the entire University to hand in
Business
artistic contributions.
Manager Spencer reported that
many of the men of the senior
class had already had their pictures
taken. He also had suggestions to
make regarding the business end
of the Hullabaloo. The success of
the book depends to a large degree
upon the advertisements, and Mr.
Spencer urged the other departments of the Board to co-operate
with the advertising manager as
much as possible.
Members of the senior class
can have their pictures taken as
soon as they obtain a slip from
"Bill" Baker, who is in charge of
the photographic department. Judging by the progress made already,
there is no reason why the 1915
Hullabaloo ought not be the best
yet. The Board wants the cooperation of the entire student
body, and believes that there will
be an immediate response.
When the meeting of the Board
was over it found awaiting it a
"Hallowe'en party." While seated
at the table a "witch" entered bearing a placard saying "No Pumpkin
Heads on the 1915 Hullabaloo
Board." She next distributed roses
to the Board. To each rose was
attached a quotation wishing success to the 1915 book. Before the
Board was able to find out who
the "witch" was, she had vanished
as quickly as she had appeared.
The "witch's" visit was taken as a
favorable omen, and the Board
now believes that the success of
the book is assured. The delightful party was broken up by all
arising and singing the class's anthem, "Whan That Aprille," etc.,
to the tune of "Good Night
Ladies."
The members of the Board are
Short, Spencer, Warren, Baker,
Merrick, Brooks, Bartlett, Troxell,
Nicholson, Lindau, Weech and
Tarr.

As announced last week, Hopkins expects to send a team to participate in the cross-country run
which will be held at Lexington,
Va., under the auspices of the
Southern Intercollegiate Track Association. The small • number of
candidates for this team indicates
clearly that the student body is
lacking in interest, or active interest, at least.
While only about ten men are to
be sent to the event at Lexington,
the number of candidates so far
is disappointing.
Practice is held every afternoon
at Homewood at 5.20 o'clock under
the direction of Coach "Joe" England. The practice itself is very
simple, and requires only a little
time each afternoon. The candidates gradually increase the distance of their run until the required
distance is reached. There can be
no doubt that such a systematic
training is of physic41 benefit to the
candidates.
The men who have been reporting at Homewood are: Penniman,
Fred Hall, Strauss, Binford, Poole,
Brower and Niles. Several of these
men, however, are not candidates
for the cross-country team. Everhard Deems, '15, manager of the
track team, urges all candidates—
old and new—for the track team
to participate in this practice at
Homewood.
The date of the meet at Lexington has not been definitely arranged, but it will probably come
in the last week of this month.
The,building of the schedule of
the 1915 track team is already being carried on by Manager Deems.
On his list are the University of
Virginia, Lehigh and Navy, besides the regular annual opponents,
and meets or meetings with representative squads may be arranged.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

THE COTILLON DATES ANNOUNCED BIBLE CLASSES ORGANIZE SLOWLY
Three Dances This Academic Year Are
to Be Held on December 4,February
12 and May 1—Finances Good.

Committee Is Still Busy Campaigning for
Students, but the Acceptances Are
Unusually Small in Number.

The organization meeting of the
Cotillon Board was held last Monday, when the dates for the three
dances of the year were fixed. The
first cotillon will take place on Friday evening, December 4. The
others will be on February 12 and
May I.
• The affairs of the Board are in
better shape than ever before, as
a good financial balance was carried
over from last season. Therefore,
the dances are expected to prove
even more elaborate functions than
heretofore.
Chairman Allen F. Voshell is
already arranging .a better system
of chaperoning. Efforts will be
made to get faculty sanction for an
advance of the closing hour from
tmidnight to one o'clock. In the
past, there has been much "complaint" of the cutting short of
after-supper dances, and the hasty
dash for the cloakroom at twelve,
when "Louie" lifts his marvelous
fingers from the keyboard and deParts.
Of course, "Louie" will be with
us again, and there can be no doubts
as to the music when he and his
ragtime band are behind the McCoy Hall palms.

The first "cabinet meeting" of the
University Young Men's Christian
Association was held last Tuesday
evening. At this meeting of the
officers of the Association, which is
held annually, plans for •the year
were discussed in detail with the
view of increasing the influence of
the Association and its work among
the students. Several officers were
also elected. A. M. Warren, of the
senior class, was made chairman of
the meetings committee.
The Bible study committee continues its call for students to join
the Bible classes. The itIvitation
cards are being returned very slowly. Dr. Swartz's class in "The Difficulties of the Bible," which was
recently organized, will meet at
seven o'clock every Thursday.
To those students who are unable to attend the classes at the
University, a most cordial invitation
is extended by the Central Young
Men's Christian Association, where
similar meetings are held every
Tuesday night. At 6.20 o'clock a
light lunch is served at the small
price of 15 cents. From 7 to 7.45
o'clock the classes will rneet. "Live
wire" talks will be given by prominent local ministers of churches of
all denominations.
In answer to the Association's
call for students to teach foreigners
the English language, another student has applied and has been assigned a class at the Fayette Street
M. E. Church. He is Alfred Niles,
of the 1916 class. Niles is the
third man to take up this work.
Three more are still needed.
As has been customary in previous years, Dr. J. M. T. Finney,
of the Medical School, will deliver
his two lectures on "Hygiene." The
lectures are given primarily for the
benefit of the freshman class, but
invitation is extended to all members of the University. The lectures are of vital interest to every
college man.
The dates of the lectures have
not been definitely decided upon.
They will, most likely, occur on
consecutive Mondays in the latter
part of this month. Dr. Abercrombie, in former years, has excused those freshmen from the
gymnasium class who attended
these lectures.

1916 Hullabaloo Organizes.

The organization meeting of the
1916 Hullabaloo Board was held in
the Trophy Room at one o'clock
Thursday.
The meeting was opened with a
Speech by Editor-in-Chief Tingley,
who gave a brief outline of the
work that is to be accomplished
during the current year. The Board
was then formally divided into
three departments: literary, art,
and business, and committees were
appointed to take charge of each
of these branches. Photographic
work is of course included under the
general head of art. The present
Junior Class has several men who
are clever with the camera, and
snap-shots of an unusual character
are promised.
Under the head of elections,
Dorsey Richardson and Miles H.
McCormick were chosen to be
members of the Board. Both of
them were assigned to the literary
department. An art editor is still
to be chosen by competition among
the class draughtsmen, and Friday,
November 20, was set as the date
on which all contributions of aspirants for the position must be submitted.
The meeting closed with a discussion of methods for financing
tile Hullabaloo. Delinquent members of the class are urged to pay
their dues as promptly as they can,
and so make the work of the Board
easier.

BALTIMORE, MD., NOV. 2, 1914.
Layfield's Injury.

The injury suffered by Quarterback Robert Layfield in Saturday's
game with Lehigh is the first accident of a serious nature to have
occurred to a Hopkins player in
many years.
He was a light man, but his speed
and pluck overcame the handicap
in weight, and he won his place on
the 'Varsity over several other candidates. He is popular and has
made a great many friends during
the month he has been at Hopkins.
It is because of this pluck and
Popularity that his friends of the
team and in the student body wish
for him a speedy recovery, and THE
NEWS-LTTER expresses this sentiment, reflecting the concern and
sympathy which are felt generally
because of his condition.
Saturday's Games and Varsity's Chances.

The decisive defeat of \Vestern
Maryland by St. John's on Saturday, 34 to o, has materially increased the complexity of speculation as to the outcome of this year's
struggle for the state championship.
Three weeks ago Maryland Agricultural College suffered defeat at
the hands of Western Maryland,
a week'later the Farmers won from
St. John's and now St. John's defeats Western Maryland by an
overwhelming score. An explanation may partly be found in the
fact that the Aggies braced after
their loss to Western Maryland and
faced St. John's with a much
stronger team than that which
played the up-state eleven; however, it is evident that the Annapolis team is putting up a good game,
and will undoubtedly be in fighting trim on Thanksgiving Day.
Circumstances point to a hard battle when Hopkins again meets its
old foe.
The other games still to be played
this year promise to be highly in-

Can Win State Championship.

The Maryland Aggies, since they
have defeated Hopkins and St.
John's, are beginning to lay claim
to the state championship.
They do not recall, however, that
they have been defeated by Western
Maryland, 20 to 13, and that St.
John's has defeated Western Maryland, 34 to o.
Thus, the race for the title becomes an almost hopeless tangle.
But the Aggies, although they have
put crimps in the aspirations of St.
John's and Hopkins, have been
"crimped" themselves by Western
Maryland. Western Maryland has
been defeated by St. John's. Should
Hopkins win from the Westminster
team, it is pointed out by followers
of the game in this state that the
championship will fall to the team
that is victorious in the HopkinsSt. John's game at Homewood on
Thanksgiving.
The state games so far have resulted:
Washington defeated Western
Maryland.
Hopkins defeated Washington.
Aggies defeated St. John's.
Aggies defeated Hopkins.
St. John's •defeated Western
Maryland.
Western Maryland defeated Aggies.

our musicians and must pay for
them ourselves. The time is close at
hand when a brass band will have to
be engaged, and it is up to the students to raise the necessary money
among themselves. The team will
need all the encouragement that the
rooters' stand can give—the coming games all promise to be hard
contests and the presence of a band
will help tremendously to make the
rooting a big success; therefore, let
every Hopkins man give all he can
to assist in making the support of
the team at the coming games as
full of "pep" as possible. The loyal

Above all, let us be on hand ourselves to a man so that when the

our players on to the best of our

Bible Study Class Meets.

.The first of the meetings of the
Bible study classes, each of which
are to assemble once a week during
the next two or three months under the leadership of the Young
Men's Christian Association, was
held at noon on 'Thursday in Levering Hall.
As outlined in his talk on Thursday, Dr. Swartz intends to take up
the study of man and to show in
what ways he is "like the image
of God." "Then," continued Dr.
Swartz, "we will study briefly the
life of God and try to explain any
actions or parts of His life that arc
not clear."
There were about twenty-five
men present at this first meeting,
and, according to the list of Secretary Sutton, about ten other men
are in the class. The next meeting
will take place on Thursday, at
noon, and all members of the class
are requested to be present.

LACROSSE GETS AN EARLY START
Aspirants for the Varsity Twelve Begin
Practicing in Cage Organization
Meeting About December 1.

Although the first lacrosse game
is less than five months off, many
of the aspirants for the Black and
Blue twelve have begun to practice in the cage. It is pleasing to
the officials in this branch of sport
that there is such a good spirit in
evidence. They also wish to give
these men a word of encouragement for constant practice will show
up when the scrimmages begin.
The. first official steps toward
opening the lacrosse season will be
the organization meeting, which is
to be held on or about December I
—just after the close of the football season. Following this meeting, regular practices will be held
in the cage and as soon as the
weather permits, Captain Troxell
will take his men to Homewood for
outdoor practice.
The chances for new players to
make the team are exceptionally
bright this year, for a number of
veterans of the game have either
been barred from playing by the
four-year limit or have failed to
return to the University. The defense department of the twelve has
suffered badly from the loss of
players. Julian Sears, who saw
four years of service on the team,
will be barred from playing; Walter D. Sutton, captain and coverpoint of last year's team, has also
played four years; Victor Bridgman, who played the point position,
has graduated; Guy Hollyday,
known in lacrosse togs as "the bearcat," will be badly missed at third
defense; Benton Beatty, who did
not return to the University, played
center last season. On the attack,
Frankie LaMotte, who is now attending the University of Wisconsin, is the only man who did not
return.
In spite of the fact.that a number
of stars were lost last year, prospects for a twelve of the usual
Hopkins' standard a r e bright.
There are a number of new men at
the University who have some
knowledge of the game from playing at preparatory schools: Richard
Woodward, Alexander Wolfe, Robert Hoffman and Frank Sutton
were all regulars on last year's City
College championship team; Mealy,
from Polytechnic, and Nelson, of
Gilman's Country School, a r e
others who have shown prowess
with the stick.
It is practically certain that
Coaches Raney Wolfe and William
Schmeisser will again head the
coaching department, with Professor Edward Hulburt, of the 1911
championship team, as assistant
coach.
There has been some delay in the
completion of the schedule, and
Manager Hiram Woodward will
not be able to announce the dates

until next week. As has been the
custom for a number of years, the
alumni will be met in the first game
on the last Saturday in March at
Homewood. The remainder of the
schedule includes the same teams
that were met last year. All of the
games will be played at Homewood,
with the exception of those with
Swarthmore and Navy, which will
be staged on our opponents'
grounds.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS-LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

VIOLIN SOUNDS SUBJECT OF STUDY

FRESHIES HOLD SECOND MEETING

Dr. Hewlett, of Physics Department, Has
Specially Equipped Room in Which
He Analyzes "Fiddle's Squeak."

The Upper Classmen Make Appeals for
Larger Support for College Activities Constitution Adopted.

Dr. Clarence Wilson Hewlett, instructor in the department of physics, has been engaged for the past
few years in analyzing the complex sound waves sent out by violins, and in measuring the distribution of energy among the partials
of the tones produced.
The experiments performed were
carried on in a room, the floor,
ceiling, and walls of which were
covered with a preparation of flax,
so that reflection of the waves
might be minimized.
About forty resonators, tuned according to the diatonic scale, were
enclosed in a wooden case, of which
the front was made of thin celluloid. In the aperture of each of
these a small mica disk, carrying a
mirror, was suspended on a fine
quartz fibre. Rays from fixed
sources of light were reflected by
these mirrors on a scale placed a
short distance in front of the apparatus, and the zero reading noted.
When the violin was bowed, the
resonator, whose frequency was the
same as the fundamental note produced on the instrument, began to
vibrate, and the disk at its opening was twisted around. The intensity of its vibration was measured by the image which the mirror cast upon the scale. Vibrations
were likewise perceived in the few
other resonators corresponding, in
..period, to the upper partials.
In order to get more marked
differences, the experiments were
carried on with violins which musicians pronounced of good quality,
and with some very inferior ones.
The difference in quality of the
tones produced manifested itself in
the even distribution of energy
among the component parts of the
notes of the better instruments and
in the total irregularity in the
others. In tile first case, a large
percentage of the total energy was
expended on the fundamental, and
a decreasing amount on the upper
partials which averaged about four
in number. In the latter, there
were frequently vibrations of 12
partials, and no regular arrangement of the distribution of energy
among the component parts was observed, all of which really amounts
to the fact that cheap violins frequently squeak.
The energy measured was, of
course, expressed in ergs.
The judging of tone quality thus
having been brought to a measurable basis, it is not too much to
expect innovations in the design of
our violins and a change for the
better.

The freshmen held their second
meeting of the year last Thursday
at one o'clock in the chapel of the
Young Men's Christian Association.
The only class business of any moment was the ratification of a constitution.
The meeting was opened by a
general "raking over the coals" by
the leaders of various student activities, who eloquently deplored the
fact that the "fresilies" had not
responded to the calling of these
activities as unitedly as has been
the custom. "Hoy" Short, editorin-chief of THE NEws - LETTER,
made a strong appeal for more candidates to compete for the freshman
editorships. It seems that only
about one-third as many 1918 men
are competing for the jobs this
year as has been the custom in previous years. C. E. Deems asked for
larger attendance to the various
Bible classes. He pointed out that
the classes prove a source of pleasure, as well as knowledge, and that
they deserved the hearty support
of the freshmen. "Tommy" Troxell advised those of the class who
desired to go out for the lacrosse
team to go over to the cage and
limber up. Edmund Spieker solicited the support of the freshmen
to help make this season a successful one for the Glee Club. President Frank Sutton appealed to the
class to uphold its honor by doing
its part to further the success of the
various student activities.
The constiutional committee (Arthur Hooper, Morton Rothschild
and Page Nelson) submitted the
constitution for ratification. It was
accepted with a few minor changes.
The question of class colors and
class pins was discussed and it was
finally decided to put the matter in
the hands of a committee.

of work in two days, how long will

William—Is it a contrac' job or

Dr. Mustard Issues New Book.

The Johns Hopkins Press announced the publication of "The
Piscatory Eclogues of Jacopo Sannavaro," edited by Dr. Wilfred P.
Mustard, collegiate professor of
Latin.
This is the second of a series of
studies in the Latin poetry of the
Renaissance, and is uniform with
the first study, "The Eclogues of
Baptista Mantuanus."
The book is dedicated to Dean
E. H. Griffin.

THE JOHNS HOPKINS NEWS—LETTER, NOVEMBER 2, 1914.

The Norman, Remington Co.

HOMEWOOD CHIMES RING AGAIN

NOT ALLOWED TO CARRY COLORS

Gilman Hall Bells Have Been Made Har-

Law Passed to Stop Socialist Demonstra-

monious and Will Now Tell the

tions Affects Harvard Students, and

Hours Without Complaint.

Neither Can Wave Red Flags.

The bells in the tower of the new
Gilman Hall at Homewood have
been filed and polished until they
are now harmonious:, and may ring
without affecting the nerves of
neighbors, at whose complaint they
were hushed three weeks ago.
When the chimes were installed
it was found that they were sadly
discordant. This alone was a cause
for complaint. But when they rang
quarter-hours at the wrong time,
neighbors notified the authorities of
the University that they were
alarmists and disturbers of the
peace. Of course people did not
understand that they had just been
installed and the false telling of
time was part of the experiments
being made by workmen to see if
the set of bells was satisfactory.
When the complaints were received, however, the bells were returned to the foundry. They have
been filed and polished, and when
returned to the tower will be in
perfect harmony.

Because the colors of Harvard
University are crimson and white,
students of the college probably
will be prevented by law from
carrying flags and pennants in parades and games in the Commonweath of Massachusetts.
Frequent Socialist demonstrations, all of them accompanied by
the waving of red flags, caused a
law to be passed prohibiting the
carrying of red flags in the State.
It was meant to apply to the Socialists, and their leaders now declare that if their followers can not
bear the flaming color, neither can
any one else, and they intend to
see to it that Harvard's crimson
receives the same treatment as their
own color. Harvard parades, they
point out, are always led by a standard bearer with a large red flag.
Theoretically' the law will prohibit Harvard's carrying a red flag,
and it is said that members of the
University student body will walk
down a Cambridge street with a
flag to be arrested and bring about
a test case of the law. The Supreme Court has already upheld a
decision affecting the Socialists,
and Harvard students believe it
would be interesting to see how the
law will be dealt out to them.
Should the judges prohibit Harvard's flags from appearing on the
streets, it is said that influential
alumni on the bench and at the bar
will see that the statute is repealed.
